TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . The respondent Government are represented by their Agent , PERSON , ORG , and , subsequently , PERSON PERSON , PERSON , of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant ’s daughter PERSON was born on CARDINAL DATE . In DATE the applicant and PERSON , his then wife , separated . Since then PERSON has been living with her mother , who was awarded custody of her . On DATE the applicant had his last contact with F.

On DATE the Berlin Tempelhof - ORG suspended the applicant ’s access to F. This judgment was upheld by ORG on DATE . On DATE ORG refused to admit the applicant ’s constitutional complaint lodged against the latter judgment .

In his first application ( no . MONEY ) to this ORG , the applicant complained , in particular , that the said court decisions suspending his access to PERSON amounted to a breach of his right to respect for his family life . He further claimed that the court proceedings concerned had not been fair . On DATE , the ORG declared admissible these complaints .

On DATE and CARDINAL DATE the applicant lodged a motion under Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW ( see ‘ Relevant domestic law’ below ) to order PERSON to provide him with further information about their daughter PERSON , notably her current place of residence .

On DATE ORG , sitting in guardianship matters , dismissed the applicant ’s motions . It rendered its decision following a hearing attended by PERSON and PERSON , then aged DATE . The applicant , who had been duly summoned , had not attended the hearing .

In its reasoning , ORG referred to its final decision of DATE according to which the applicant was entitled to CARDINAL photograph of PERSON each year together with the final school report in DATE . Furthermore , PERSON had been ordered to supply the applicant with copies of the interim school report of DATE and of any further final school reports or reports on subsequent professional training , respectively . The applicant was also entitled to information about his daughter ’s health DATE and to immediate notice about any change in her state of health .

ORG found that the applicant was not entitled to be informed of his daughter ’s place of residence and of the address of her school on the ground that such information was contrary to the child ’s well - being . It noted that the applicant did not have custody of F. and therefore had no power of co - determination in school matters . His right of access to F. had been suspended . In the court ’s view , the applicant claimed the information in question only in order to establish access to F. , which was contrary to her best interests . Moreover , PERSON feared reprisals . The court further noted that PERSON , having been heard by ORG and in court on DATE , refused any contacts with her father .
ORG also dismissed the applicant ’s request for coercive measures , noting that PERSON had complied with the court order of DATE .

On DATE ORG , having heard the applicant and PERSON , dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . ORG considered that ORG had not exceeded its margin of appreciation when deciding that no information about the child ’s whereabouts should be disclosed . Having regard to the strained relations between the parents , this had been in the child ’s best interests . The information requested was not of such an importance that it had to be disclosed against PERSON ’s express will . ORG took into consideration that in a decision dated DATE , ORG had initiated measures to re - establish contacts between the applicant and his daughter cautiously .

Following the entry into force of the amended LAW , the applicant lodged a second request to be informed of his daughter ’s place of residence on DATE . He argued that he needed PERSON ’s address in order to be able to maintain a minimum of contacts with her , because having to send letters to her via ORG was discriminating against him .

On DATE ORG , sitting in family matters , dismissed the applicant ’s request . It confirmed that the daughter ’s interest to avoid the risk of contacts with the applicant outweighed the latter ’s interest to be informed of her address pursuant to LAW of LAW ( see ‘ Relevant domestic law’ below ) .

In this connection , ORG noted that on DATE it had decided in a different set of proceedings instituted by the applicant that his access to F. remained suspended . It had found in that judgment that F. , then aged DATE , had expressly refused any contacts with her father and was crushed between her GPE conflicting interests . In the case before it , the ORG therefore had to avoid a deterioration of PERSON ’s tense mental state , which had not least been caused by never - ending court proceedings and examinations by psychological experts .

On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . Referring to its hearing of the parties on DATE in the context of further proceedings concerning the applicant ’s right of access , it observed that the relations between PERSON and the applicant remained strained . Therefore , the applicant was not entitled to information about his daughter ’s whereabouts . It noted that since the suspension of access DATE , PERSON had only once , in DATE , seen the applicant outside court . In these circumstances , any risk that the applicant would go to the house where PERSON and PERSON were living had to be avoided .

On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint with ORG , comprising CARDINAL pages . He claimed that the decision of ORG not to order the disclosure of his daughter ’s address violated his right to respect for his family life , his right to be heard and the principle of equality .
On DATE ORG , without giving further reasons , refused to admit the applicant ’s constitutional complaint .

On DATE the ORG ordered PERSON to pay a coercive penalty of CARDINAL ORG for failure to comply with its order dated DATE to supply the applicant with certain information about F.’ personal circumstances .

On DATE ORG confirmed the judgment of ORG delivered on DATE that the applicant ’s access to F. remain suspended . It found that it would be against the best interests of F. , who had almost attained the age of majority , to order contacts against her firmly expressed will .
On DATE F. attained the age of majority .

Before the entry into force of the amended LAW ) on DATE , the relevant provision of LAW concerning a parent ’s right to information about his or her under age child born in wedlock was worded as follows :
Section CARDINAL

“ CARDINAL . A parent not having custody who has a legitimate interest in obtaining information about the child ’s personal circumstances may request such information from the person having custody in so far as this is in keeping with the child ’s best interests . The guardianship court shall rule on any dispute over the right to information . ”
The relevant provision in force since DATE , Section CARDINAL of LAW , provides as follows :

“ Each parent who has a legitimate interest in obtaining information about the child ’s personal circumstances may request such information from the other parent in so far as this is not contrary to the child ’s best interests . The family court shall rule on any dispute . ”

Proceedings in family matters are governed , inter alia , by LAW Contentious Proceedings ( PERSON über die ORG der freiwilligen PERSON ) . Pursuant to Sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of that Act , as applicable to the proceedings concerning the applicant ’s first request for information , a further appeal ( PERSON ) to ORG lay against a decision of ORG . If an appellant wished to lodge his further appeal in writing , his submissions had to be signed by a lawyer ( Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the said Act ) .
